page.title: 11LANDSCAPE OF THE S. DOWNS
page.content: The landscape typical of the S.Downs is familiar to most people from photo- graphs but it is the N.face of the downs with its steep slopes & scarpes which most often appear. The wooded S.slopes are less familiar. The downs above Heyshott & Graffham illustrate the typical shapes of downland gently undulating curves, steep N.face often pitted by old quarries, thickly wooded gullies & the gentler slopes on the S.side. The soil is composed of underlying chalk & flint with a thin covering of clay. Chalk & flints have broken through the clay where it has been ploughed & the ground is very rough. The climate is mild, with average rainfall & even in winter the snow is seldom more than a thin covering. At times the prevailing S.W. wind is very strong.
